questions.question: Describe AAPL's main business and products.
questions.ground_truth_value: Apple Inc. is a preeminent American multinational technology company renowned for its innovative consumer electronics, software, and online services.
questions.ground_truth_formatted: Apple Inc. designs, manufactures, and markets smartphones (iPhone), tablets (iPad), computers (Mac), wearables (Apple Watch), and provides digital services including the App Store, Apple Music, and iCloud.

questions.question: A company has two mutually exclusive projects. Project A requires $100,000 investment and returns $150,000 in Year 1. Project B requires $100,000 investment and returns $180,000 in Year 2. At what discount rate are the two projects equally attractive (i.e., have equal NPV)?

components.name: methodology
components.description: Set up NPV equality equation correctly

questions.question: An investor holds a portfolio of two stocks: Stock X (60% weight, beta=1.2) and Stock Y (40% weight, beta=0.8). The risk-free rate is 3% and the market risk premium is 6%. If the investor wants to reduce the portfolio beta to exactly 1.0 by adjusting only the weight of Stock X (and putting the remainder in the risk-free asset), what should be the new weight of Stock X?
calculation_steps: New portfolio: w_X in Stock X, (1-w_X) in risk-free asset
Note: The problem asks to adjust only Stock X weight with remainder in risk-free
But wait - re-reading: investor currently holds X and Y, wants to adjust X weight
If selling Y and buying risk-free: new beta = w_X * 1.2
Actually, if keeping Y at 40% and adjusting X:
Let w_X be new weight of X, w_Y = 0.4, w_rf = 1 - w_X - 0.4
Hmm, the question says adjusting ONLY Stock X weight with remainder in risk-free
But if we keep Stock Y constant at 40%:
We need to reconsider - selling some X and putting in risk-free
Let's say new weights: w_X, 0.4, 0.6 - w_X (in risk-free)
Actually the simplest reading: sell all Y, put only X and risk-free

components.name: setup
components.description: Correctly set up portfolio beta equation

components.name: answer
components.description: Answer approximately 50% or 83.3% depending on interpretation

questions.question: A zero-coupon bond with face value $1,000 matures in 5 years and currently trades at $680. A coupon bond with the same maturity pays 6% annual coupons and trades at par ($1,000). If the yield curve is flat, what is the arbitrage-free price of a 5-year bond paying 8% annual coupons with face value $1,000?
calculation_steps: Verify with 6% coupon at par: only works if YTM = coupon rate = 6%
Contradiction - so yield curve is NOT flat in traditional sense
Re-interpret: if 6% coupon trades at par, YTM = 6%
For 8% coupon bond at 6% flat yield:

components.name: yield_extraction
components.description: Correctly extracted yield from given bonds

components.name: calculation
components.description: Correctly computed present value of cash flows

questions.question: Company ABC has EBIT of $10 million, depreciation of $2 million, capital expenditures of $3 million, and working capital increase of $1 million. The tax rate is 25%. What is the Free Cash Flow to Firm (FCFF)?
calculation_steps: FCFF = EBIT × (1 - Tax Rate) + Depreciation - CapEx - ΔWorking Capital

components.name: tax_shield
components.description: Correctly applied tax rate to EBIT

questions.question: An investor buys a call option with strike $100 for $8 and simultaneously sells a call option with strike $110 for $3 (both on the same underlying, same expiration). What is the maximum profit, maximum loss, and breakeven price of this bull call spread?
calculation_steps: Net premium paid = $8 - $3 = $5 (this is max loss)
Max profit = Strike difference - Net premium = ($110 - $100) - $5 = $5

components.name: max_loss
components.description: Correctly identified max loss as net premium $5

questions.question: A firm has $500 million in assets, a debt-to-equity ratio of 1.5, and pays 6% interest on its debt. The corporate tax rate is 30%. If the firm's ROA (return on assets) is 10%, what is the ROE (return on equity)?
calculation_steps: D/E = 1.5, so if E = x, then D = 1.5x
D + E = 500M, so 1.5x + x = 500M, x = 200M (Equity), D = 300M (Debt)

components.name: capital_structure
components.description: Correctly decomposed D/E into debt and equity amounts

questions.question: In a Modigliani-Miller world with no taxes, Firm A is all-equity with 1 million shares at $50 each. Firm B is identical but has $20 million in debt at 5% interest, with remaining equity value of $30 million. An investor owns 10% of Firm A's equity. Describe how this investor can create a 'homemade' leveraged position equivalent to owning 10% of Firm B's equity, and calculate the net investment required.
questions.ground_truth_formatted: Borrow $2M personally, invest $5M in Firm A (buy $3M net), equivalent to 10% of B's equity
calculation_steps: 10% of Firm B equity = $3M investment, but gets levered returns
To replicate: Investor borrows 10% of Firm B's debt = $2M
Invests this + own $3M = $5M in Firm A shares (10% of A)
Net investment = $3M (same as buying 10% of B)
Returns will match due to homemade leverage

components.name: mm_understanding
components.description: Understood MM proposition and homemade leverage concept

components.name: replication_strategy
components.description: Correctly described borrowing and investing strategy

components.name: amounts
components.description: Calculated correct amounts: borrow $2M, invest $5M in A

questions.question: A company's stock price follows a binomial model. Currently at $100, it can go up 20% or down 15% each period. The risk-free rate is 5% per period. What is the risk-neutral probability of an up move?

An investor can choose between: (A) receiving $10,000 today, or (B) receiving $12,500 in 3 years. The investor's opportunity cost of capital is 8% annually. Which option has higher present value and by how much?
calculation_steps: PV of Option A = $10,000 (already present value)

components.name: pv_calculation
components.description: Correctly calculated PV of future amount

components.name: answer
components.description: Identified Option A as better, difference ~$75

questions.question: A pension fund has liabilities with duration of 15 years. It holds two bonds: Bond A with duration 5 years and Bond B with duration 20 years. What percentage of the portfolio should be invested in Bond B to immunize the portfolio against interest rate changes?
calculation_steps: To immunize: Portfolio duration = Liability duration
Let w = weight in Bond B, (1-w) = weight in Bond A

components.name: equation_setup
components.description: Set up weighted duration equation correctly

questions.question: A company has operating leverage (DOL) of 2.5 and financial leverage (DFL) of 1.6. If sales increase by 10%, by what percentage will EPS change?
calculation_steps: Degree of Total Leverage (DTL) = DOL × DFL
% Change in EPS = DTL × % Change in Sales

questions.question: Stock XYZ has an expected return of 12% and standard deviation of 25%. The risk-free rate is 4%. An investor wants to create a portfolio with expected return of 16% using Stock XYZ and the risk-free asset. What is the standard deviation of this portfolio and how much leverage is required?
questions.ground_truth_formatted: Standard deviation: 37.5%, Leverage: 1.5x (150% in stock, -50% in risk-free)
calculation_steps: w = 1.5 (150% in stock, meaning -50% in risk-free = borrowing)

components.name: leverage_interpretation
components.description: Understood that w > 1 means borrowing at risk-free rate

questions.question: A perpetual bond pays $50 annually. If interest rates rise from 5% to 6%, what is the percentage change in the bond's price?
calculation_steps: Price of perpetuity = Annual payment / Interest rate

components.name: perpetuity_formula
components.description: Used P = C/r for perpetuity valuation

components.name: both_prices
components.description: Calculated both initial and new prices correctly

questions.question: Company X can borrow at fixed rate 8% or floating LIBOR+1%. Company Y can borrow at fixed rate 10% or floating LIBOR+2%. If they enter an interest rate swap where X borrows floating and Y borrows fixed, and they split the gains equally, what fixed rate does X effectively pay after the swap?
calculation_steps: X has comparative advantage in fixed (larger spread)
X borrows floating at LIBOR+1%, enters swap
Y borrows fixed at 10%, enters swap

questions.question: A company has 100,000 shares outstanding at $25 per share. It announces a 3-for-2 stock split. After the split, what is the expected price per share and how many shares will be outstanding?
calculation_steps: 3-for-2 split means for every 2 shares, shareholder receives 3

questions.question: Using put-call parity, if a European call option on a non-dividend paying stock is priced at $8, the stock price is $100, the strike price is $95, and the risk-free rate is 5% with 1 year to expiration, what should be the price of the corresponding put option?
calculation_steps: Put-Call Parity: C + PV(K) = P + S
This is negative which indicates arbitrage opportunity or mispricing
Let me recalculate: P = C - S + PV(K)
Negative put price is impossible - means call is overpriced
Or recheck: C + PV(K) = P + S
Actually the formula confirms the call is expensive relative to parity
If we use P = C + K*e^(-rT) - S
Given the question setup, expected answer around $1-2

components.name: pv_calculation
components.description: Correctly calculated present value of strike

components.name: answer
components.description: Calculated put price (note: may be negative indicating arbitrage)

questions.question: An investor uses the Gordon Growth Model to value a stock. The stock just paid a dividend of $2.00, dividends are expected to grow at 6% annually forever, and the required return is 10%. What is the intrinsic value of the stock?
calculation_steps: Gordon Growth Model: P = D1 / (r - g)

questions.question: A trader observes the following: Spot EUR/USD = 1.10, 1-year forward EUR/USD = 1.12, 1-year USD interest rate = 5%, 1-year EUR interest rate = 3%. Is there a covered interest arbitrage opportunity? If so, describe the strategy and calculate the risk-free profit per $1 million.
calculation_steps: Covered Interest Parity: F = S × (1 + r_USD) / (1 + r_EUR)
EUR is cheap in forward market relative to parity
Arbitrage: Borrow USD, convert to EUR, invest in EUR, sell EUR forward
Reverse: Borrow EUR, convert to USD, invest in USD, buy EUR forward
Profit approximately $1,272 per $1M (or $7,273 if scaling differently)

components.name: cip_formula
components.description: Correctly stated covered interest parity formula

components.name: profit_calc
components.description: Calculated profit (varies based on exact calculation)
